title: Loop Control: break, continue, and pass
concept:
Imagine you're searching through a stack of 100 papers for one specific document:

  • Normal loop: Check all 100 papers, even after finding the one you need (wasteful!)
  • With break: Stop immediately when you find it - paper #23? Done! Skip the remaining 77.

Or imagine processing a list of test scores, but some entries are marked as "invalid":

  • Normal loop: Try to process every entry, causing errors on invalid ones
  • With continue: Skip invalid entries, continue with the next valid one

This is loop control - fine-tuning how loops execute with three special statements:

  1. break: "Stop the loop entirely and exit"
  2. continue: "Skip the rest of this iteration and move to the next"
  3. pass: "Do nothing, but don't leave this block empty"

Real-World Examples:

  • Password attempts (break):
    WHILE attempts < 3:
        Get password
        IF correct ‚Üí break (exit loop)
        attempts++
  • Processing records (continue):
    FOR each record:
        IF record is corrupted ‚Üí continue (skip it)
        Process valid record
  • Menu system (break):
    WHILE True:
        Show menu
        Get choice
        IF choice == "quit" ‚Üí break
  • Data filtering (continue):
    FOR each email:
        IF is_spam ‚Üí continue
        Add to inbox

These statements give you surgical precision over loop execution!

code_example.code:
# Loop Control: break, continue, and pass

# Example 1: break - Exit Loop Early
print("=== Finding a Number (break) ===")

for num in range(1, 11):
    print(f"Checking {num}")
    
    if num == 5:
        print("Found 5! Stopping search.")
        break  # Exit the loop immediately
    
print("Loop ended\n")
# Output: Checks 1-5, then stops

# Example 2: continue - Skip Current Iteration
print("=== Printing Odd Numbers (continue) ===")

for num in range(1, 11):
    if num % 2 == 0:  # If even
        continue  # Skip to next iteration
    
    print(num)  # Only prints odd numbers

print()

# Example 3: Practical break - Password System
print("=== Password System (3 attempts) ===")

correct_password = "python123"
attempts = 0
max_attempts = 3

while attempts < max_attempts:
    password = input("Enter password: ")
    attempts = attempts + 1
    
    if password == correct_password:
        print("‚úì Access granted!")
        break  # Stop asking for password
    else:
        remaining = max_attempts - attempts
        if remaining > 0:
            print(f"‚ùå Incorrect. {remaining} attempts remaining.")

if attempts == max_attempts and password != correct_password:
    print("üîí Account locked!")

print()

# Example 4: continue for Data Filtering
print("=== Processing Valid Scores ===")

scores = [85, -1, 92, 150, 78, -5, 88]  # Some invalid scores

total = 0
valid_count = 0

for score in scores:
    # Skip invalid scores (negative or > 100)
    if score < 0 or score > 100:
        print(f"Skipping invalid score: {score}")
        continue  # Skip to next iteration
    
    # Process valid score
    print(f"Processing valid score: {score}")
    total = total + score
    valid_count = valid_count + 1

average = total / valid_count
print(f"\nAverage of valid scores: {average}")
print()

# Example 5: Loop with else Clause
print("=== Searching for a Value (with else) ===")

numbers = [1, 3, 5, 7, 9]
search_for = 6

for num in numbers:
    if num == search_for:
        print(f"Found {search_for}!")
        break
else:
    # Runs only if loop completed without break
    print(f"{search_for} not found in the list")

print()

# Example 6: pass - Placeholder
print("=== Using pass ===")

for i in range(5):
    if i == 2:
        pass  # TODO: Add special handling later
    else:
        print(f"Processing {i}")

print()

# Example 7: Prime Number Checker (break with else)
print("=== Prime Number Checker ===")

number = 17

if number < 2:
    print(f"{number} is not prime")
else:
    for i in range(2, number):
        if number % i == 0:
            print(f"{number} is not prime (divisible by {i})")
            break
    else:
        # Only runs if loop completed without break
        print(f"{number} is prime!")

print()

# Example 8: Menu System with break
print("=== Simple Menu ===")

while True:  # Infinite loop
    print("\n1. Say Hello")
    print("2. Say Goodbye")
    print("3. Exit")
    
    choice = input("Choose an option: ")
    
    if choice == "1":
        print("Hello!")
    elif choice == "2":
        print("Goodbye!")
    elif choice == "3":
        print("Exiting program...")
        break  # Exit the infinite loop
    else:
        print("Invalid choice!")

print("Program ended.")

syntax_breakdown:
The break Statement:

for item in sequence:
    if condition:
        break  # Exit loop immediately
    # Rest of loop body
# Code here runs after break

What break does:

  1. Immediately exits the innermost loop
  2. Skips any remaining iterations
  3. Continues with code after the loop

Visual Flow:

for num in range(1, 6):
    if num == 3:
        break  # ‚Üê Exit here
    print(num)
print("Done")

# Output:
# 1
# 2
# Done
# (Never prints 3, 4, 5 - loop exited early)

The continue Statement:

for item in sequence:
    if condition:
        continue  # Skip rest, go to next iteration
    # This code is skipped when continue runs
    process(item)

What continue does:

  1. Skips remaining code in current iteration
  2. Jumps to the next iteration
  3. Loop continues normally

Visual Flow:

for num in range(1, 6):
    if num == 3:
        continue  # ‚Üê Skip when num is 3
    print(num)

# Output:
# 1
# 2
# 4  (skipped 3!)
# 5
# (Loop continued, just skipped one iteration)

The pass Statement:

for item in sequence:
    if condition:
        pass  # Do nothing (placeholder)
    else:
        process(item)

What pass does:

  • Literally nothing - it's a placeholder
  • Used when syntax requires a statement but you have nothing to do
  • Common in early development ("TODO: implement this later")

Example Uses:

# Placeholder for future code:
for item in data:
    if item.needs_special_handling():
        pass  # TODO: Add special handling
    else:
        process(item)

# Empty function (syntax requires a body):
def coming_soon():
    pass  # Will implement later

# Empty if block:
if condition:
    pass  # Nothing to do for this case
else:
    do_something()

Loop else Clause (Advanced):

for item in sequence:
    if found_what_we_need:
        break
else:
    # Runs ONLY if loop completed without break
    print("Didn't find it")

How it works:

  • else block runs if loop finishes normally (no break)
  • else block is skipped if break was executed
  • Useful for search operations

Example - Searching:

students = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]
search_for = "David"

for student in students:
    if student == search_for:
        print(f"Found {search_for}!")
        break
else:
    # Only runs if we never broke
    print(f"{search_for} not in class")

# Output: David not in class

Found "Alice"YesNo
Found "David" (not in list)NoYes

break vs continue vs return:

StatementExitsEffect
breakLoopExit loop, continue after it
continueCurrent iterationSkip to next iteration
returnFunctionExit function entirely (Module 6)
passNothingDo nothing, continue normally

Common Patterns:

1. Early Exit (break)

# Search and stop when found
for item in large_list:
    if item == target:
        print("Found it!")
        break  # No need to keep searching

2. Skip Invalid Data (continue)

# Process only valid entries
for entry in data:
    if not entry.is_valid():
        continue  # Skip invalid entries
    process(entry)  # Only valid ones reach here

3. User-Controlled Loop (break)

# Infinite loop until user quits
while True:
    action = input("Command: ")
    if action == "quit":
        break
    handle(action)

4. Flag Alternative (else)

# Without else (old way):
found = False
for item in items:
    if item == target:
        found = True
        break
if not found:
    print("Not found")

# With else (cleaner):
for item in items:
    if item == target:
        break
else:
    print("Not found")

Common Mistakes:

  1. Using break/continue outside loops:
    # ERROR:
if condition:
    break  # SyntaxError! break only works in loops
  2. Forgetting break in infinite loops:
    # INFINITE LOOP:
while True:
    print("Running forever!")
    # Forgot break statement!

# CORRECT:
while True:
    if should_stop:
        break
  3. Confusing break with return:
    def search(items):
    for item in items:
        if item == target:
            break  # Exits loop, but stays in function
    print("After loop")  # This still runs
    
    # Use return to exit function:
    for item in items:
        if item == target:
            return item  # Exits function entirely

exercise.instructions:
Build a Number Search and Statistics Program that processes a list of numbers with the following features:

  1. Search for a specific number and stop when found (break)
  2. Skip negative numbers when calculating average (continue)
  3. Use loop else to report if number wasn't found

Requirements:

  • Ask user for a number to search for
  • Loop through the list: [23, -5, 42, 17, -3, 8, 56, 12, -9, 34]
  • If the number is found, print its position and stop searching
  • While searching, skip negative numbers when calculating the average
  • If not found, print a "not found" message
  • Display the average of positive numbers

Example output (searching for 42):

=== Number Search and Statistics ===

Enter a number to search for: 42

Searching...
Skipping negative: -5
Found 42 at position 2!

Average of positive numbers encountered: 32.5
(Processed: 23, 42)

Example output (searching for 99):

Enter a number to search for: 99

Searching...
Skipping negative: -5
Skipping negative: -3
Skipping negative: -9
99 not found in the list.

Average of positive numbers: 27.42
(Processed all: 23, 42, 17, 8, 56, 12, 34)
exercise.starter_code:
# Number Search and Statistics Program
# Uses break, continue, and loop else

print("=== Number Search and Statistics ===")
print()

# The data
numbers = [23, -5, 42, 17, -3, 8, 56, 12, -9, 34]

# Get search target
target = int(input("Enter a number to search for: "))

print("\nSearching...")

# YOUR CODE HERE:
# Initialize variables for statistics
total = 0
count = 0
processed = []  # Track which positive numbers we processed

# Loop through the list with enumeration (position tracking)
for position, num in enumerate(numbers):
    
    # Skip negative numbers (continue)
    if :  # If negative
        print(f"Skipping negative: {num}")
        continue  # Skip to next iteration
    
    # Add to running total for positive numbers
    total = total + num
    count = count + 1
    processed.append(num)
    
    # Check if this is the target (break)
    if :  # If found
        print(f"Found {target} at position {position}!")
        break  # Exit loop early

else:
    # Runs only if loop completed without break
    print(f"{target} not found in the list.")

# Calculate and display average
if count > 0:
    average = total / count
    print(f"\nAverage of positive numbers encountered: {average:.2f}")
    print(f"(Processed: {', '.join(map(str, processed))})")
else:
    print("\nNo positive numbers encountered.")
exercise.hint: For skipping negatives, check if num < 0 and use continue. For finding the target, check if num == target and use break. The else clause after the for loop will automatically run only if break was never executed. Use enumerate(numbers) to get both position and value.

How the Solution Works:

1. Setup and Initialization

numbers = [23, -5, 42, 17, -3, 8, 56, 12, -9, 34]
target = int(input("Enter number: "))

total = 0      # Running sum
count = 0      # How many positives
processed = [] # List of positives seen

2. The Loop with enumerate()

for position, num in enumerate(numbers):

enumerate() gives us both the index (position) and the value (num):

positionnum

......

3. Continue for Negative Numbers

if num < 0:
    print(f"Skipping negative: {num}")
    continue  # ‚Üê Skip rest, go to next iteration

# Code below here doesn't run for negatives!
total = total + num  # Only positives reach here

Execution flow with num = -5:

  1. Check: num < 0? Yes (-5 < 0)
  2. Print "Skipping negative: -5"
  3. Execute continue
  4. Jump to next iteration (skip total += num)

4. Processing Positive Numbers

# This code only runs for positive numbers
total = total + num
count = count + 1
processed.append(num)

Since negatives hit continue, only positives reach this code!

5. Break When Found

if num == target:
    print(f"Found {target} at position {position}!")
    break  # ‚Üê Exit loop immediately

If target is 42 and we're at position 2:

  1. Check: num == 42? Yes
  2. Print "Found 42 at position 2!"
  3. Execute break
  4. Exit loop (skip remaining numbers)

6. Loop else Clause

for position, num in enumerate(numbers):
    # ... loop body ...
    if num == target:
        break  # If this runs, else is skipped
else:
    # Only runs if we NEVER broke
    print(f"{target} not found")

Why This Pattern is Powerful:

  1. continue: Clean data filtering without nested ifs
  2. break: Efficient early exit (why check remaining if found?)
  3. else: Avoid flag variables (found = True/False)

Without else (old way):

found = False  # Need a flag variable
for num in numbers:
    if num == target:
        found = True
        break
if not found:  # Check flag after loop
    print("Not found")

With else (cleaner):

for num in numbers:
    if num == target:
        break
else:  # Automatic, no flag needed
    print("Not found")

Common Mistakes:

  1. Not tracking positives separately:
    # WRONG: Count doesn't match total
for num in numbers:
    if num < 0:
        continue
    total += num
count = len(numbers)  # Includes negatives! Wrong!

# CORRECT: Increment count only for positives
count = 0
for num in numbers:
    if num < 0:
        continue
    total += num
    count += 1  # Only increment for positives
  2. Forgetting to break:
    # INEFFICIENT:
for num in numbers:
    if num == target:
        print("Found!")  # Prints but keeps looping
# Checks all remaining numbers unnecessarily

# EFFICIENT:
for num in numbers:
    if num == target:
        print("Found!")
        break  # Stop immediately

key_takeaways:
• break exits the loop immediately, skipping remaining iterations
  • continue skips the rest of current iteration, moves to next
  • pass does nothing (placeholder for future code)
  • Loop else runs only if loop completes without break
  • Use break for: Early exit, search operations, user-controlled loops
  • Use continue for: Skipping invalid data, filtering, conditional processing
  • Use else for: Search validation, avoiding flag variables
  • break/continue work in: Both for and while loops
  • They only affect: The innermost loop they're in

Quick Reference:

# break: "Stop the loop"
for item in items:
    if found_it:
        break  # Exit loop

# continue: "Skip to next iteration"
for item in items:
    if skip_this:
        continue  # Next iteration
    process(item)

# pass: "Do nothing"
for item in items:
    if special_case:
        pass  # Placeholder
    else:
        process(item)

# else: "If loop wasn't broken"
for item in items:
    if item == target:
        break
else:
    print("Not found")  # Only if no break

When to Use Each:

ScenarioStatement
Found what you needbreak
Skip invalid/unwanted itemscontinue
Empty block placeholderpass
Detect "not found" caseelse

Before Moving On:

Make sure you can:

  • Use break to exit loops early
  • Use continue to skip iterations
  • Understand when loop else executes
  • Explain the difference between break and continue
  • Choose the right control statement for each scenario
